column1: Port Sudan (Arabic: بور سودان‎ Būr Sūdān) is a port city in eastern Sudan
column2: and the capital of the state of Red Sea. As of 2007
column4: 725 residents. Located on the Red Sea
column5: it is the Republic of Sudan's main port city.

column1: Port Sudan was built in 1905 to replace Suakin. An oil pipeline was built between the port and Khartoum in 1977.
The city has an oil refinery and handles the majority of the country's international trade. Major exports include oilseed
column3: and hides and skins. Imports include construction materials

column1: The city has a modern container-port to handle imports and exports. The main airport is Port Sudan New International Airport. There is now a tarred road linking Port Sudan to Khartoum via Atbara. Port Sudan also has a rail link with Khartoum. There is also an international ferry from Jeddah.
The city is home to the Red Sea University
Places of worship are predominantly Muslim mosques
column2: but there are also Christian churches and temples including the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Khartoum (Catholic Church)
column4: and Presbyterian Church in Sudan (World Communion of Reformed Churches).

column1: Port Sudan has a hot desert climate (Köppen: BWh) with extremely hot summers and moderately hot winters
column2: requiring the acquisition of fresh water from Wadi Arba'at in the Red Sea Hills and from salt-evaporating pans. Temperatures can easily exceed 30 °C (86 °F) in winter and 45 °C (113 °F) in summer. Over 90% of the annual rainfall falls between October and January
column4: with the wettest month on record being November 1947 with 182 millimetres (7.2 in)
column5: whilst the wettest year was from July 1923 to June 1924 with 231 millimetres (9.1 in). Average annual rainfall is 76 millimetres (3.0 in)
column6: and no rainfall occurred between January 1983 and June 1984. The  mean temperature year round (the average of all daily highs and nighttime lows) is 28.4 °C (83.1 °F).

column1: The population consists mainly of Arabs
column2: with small Asian and European minorities.
